Event: Arrives in Bethany six days before the Passover to stay with his friends.
Dines at the home of Simon the leper where Mary anoints him with oil.
Departs from Bethany mounted on a donkey's colt to travel toward the city.
Passes through Bethphage on the road approaching Jerusalem from the east.
Enters the city in a triumphal entry while being hailed as King.
Teaches in the temple and heals the blind and the lame who come to him.
Departs from the temple area in the evening to return to Bethany.
Arrives in Bethany and spends the night there.
Departs from Bethany early in the morning to return to Jerusalem.
Arrives in Jerusalem and cleanses the temple a second time of those using it for commerce.
Departs from the city in the evening to stay overnight in Bethany.
Arrives in Bethany to spend the night.
Departs from Bethany on Tuesday morning to return to the temple.
Arrives at the temple and scathingly denounces the religious hypocrisy of the scribes and Pharisees.
Departs from the temple area and travels to the Mount of Olives.
Arrives at the mountain and predicts the destruction of Jerusalem and the sign of his presence.
Departs for the city of Jerusalem on Thursday afternoon to observe the Passover.
Arrives in an upper room to celebrate the Passover meal with his twelve apostles.
Institutes the Memorial of his death and dismisses Judas Iscariot.
Departs from the upper room and travels toward the garden across the Kidron Valley.
Arrives at the garden of olive trees to pray with his disciples.
Is betrayed by Judas and arrested by an armed mob in the garden.
Arrives at the house of Caiaphas to be tried by the high priest and the Sanhedrin.
Stands trial before Pontius Pilate in the governor's palace.
Departs for the place of execution while carrying his torture stake.
Arrives at the place outside the city and is impaled on a torture stake.
Dies on the torture stake at approximately 3:00 p.m. on Friday.
Is resurrected from the dead on the third day and appears to his disciples.
Arrives in Galilee and appears to seven apostles at the Sea of Galilee.
Appears to a large group of over five hundred followers on a mountain.
Arrives back in the vicinity of the city for his final meeting with the apostles.
Ascends to heaven in the presence of his disciples on the fortieth day after his resurrection.
Paul is born in Tarsus, a prominent city of Cilicia.
Saul approves of the murder of Stephen and begins a campaign of vicious persecution against followers of Christ.
Saul asks the high priest for letters to the synagogues in Damascus authorizing him to arrest those belonging to The Way.
Saul departs for Damascus to search out disciples of Christ and bring them bound to Jerusalem.
Saul is blinded by a light from heaven and commissioned as a witness as Jesus reveals himself to the persecutor.
Saul arrives in the city blind and remains without sight or food for three days until Ananias restores his sight.
Saul is baptized and immediately begins preaching in the synagogues that Jesus is the Son of God.
Saul departs for Arabia after his conversion possibly for quiet meditation on the Scriptures.
Saul arrives in Arabia following his conversion to Christianity.
Saul remains in Arabia following his conversion to Christianity.
Saul departs from Arabia to return to Damascus.
Saul arrives back in Damascus and continues preaching until he escapes a murder plot in a wicker basket.
Saul departs for Jerusalem to visit the apostles for the first time since his conversion.
Saul arrives in Jerusalem to visit Peter and stays for fifteen days while speaking boldly in the name of the Lord.
Saul departs for Caesarea after brothers learn of a plot by Greek-speaking Jews to kill him.
Saul arrives at the seaport and is sent off to Tarsus.
Saul departs the seaport of Caesarea to return to his hometown.
Saul arrives in his hometown to begin several silent years of ministry.
Paul continues his ministry in his hometown of Tarsus.

Paul is found by Barnabas and departs with him to Antioch.
Paul arrives in Syrian Antioch and spends a whole year teaching a large crowd in the congregation.
Paul departs for Jerusalem with Barnabas to carry out a relief ministration due to a major famine.
Paul arrives in the city and completes the relief work before returning to Antioch.
Paul arrives back at his home base with Barnabas and John Mark.

Paul arrives at the port town and sails away to Cyprus.
Paul arrives on Cyprus and begins proclaiming the word of God in the synagogues.
Paul arrives at the provincial capital and blinds the sorcerer Bar-Jesus leading to the conversion of Sergius Paulus.
Paul and his companions put out to sea from Paphos for Asia Minor.
Paul arrives in Pamphylia where John Mark leaves his companions to return to Jerusalem.
Paul departs from Perga and heads north through the mountains to Antioch in Pisidia.
Paul arrives in Pisidian Antioch and gives a powerful witness in the synagogue on the Sabbath.
Paul is thrown out of the city due to Jewish instigation and departs for Iconium.
Paul arrives and speaks in the synagogue helping many Jews and Greeks to become believers.
Paul departs for Lystra after learning of a plot to stone him and Barnabas.
Paul arrives and heals a lame man but is later stoned by a mob and dragged outside the city.
Paul survives the stoning and departs for Derbe the following day.
Paul arrives and declares the good news making quite a few disciples.
Paul departs to return to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch to strengthen the disciples and appoint elders.
Paul arrives and preaches in Perga before going to Attalia.
Paul arrives at the port and departs by ship for Antioch in Syria.
Paul arrives back at his home base and reports to the congregation how God had opened the door to faith.
Paul departs for Jerusalem to settle a dispute regarding the circumcision of non-Jewish believers.
Paul arrives and meets with the apostles and older men who decide that circumcision is not a requirement for Gentiles.
Paul departs for Antioch to deliver the letter from the governing body.
Paul arrives and stays for some time teaching and declaring the good news.
Paul departs with Silas on his second missionary tour after a sharp burst of anger separates him from Barnabas.
Paul arrives and selects the young man Timothy to accompany him and he also circumcises him.
Paul and his companions travel through the eastern part of old Phrygia.
Paul arrives and sees a vision of a Macedonian man entreating him for help.
Paul and his missionary companions sail from Troas for Macedonia in Europe.
Paul arrives at the port of Philippi in NE Macedonia.
Paul arrives and is eventually imprisoned with Silas but miraculously released by an earthquake.
Paul departs for Thessalonica via Amphipolis and Apollonia.
Paul arrives and reasons from the Scriptures for three Sabbaths but departs by night due to a riot.
Paul arrives and preaches to noble-minded Jews who carefully examine the Scriptures daily.
Paul departs for the sea due to trouble caused by Jews from Thessalonica.
Paul arrives and speaks to the philosophers on the Areopagus about the Unknown God.
Paul departs alone from Athens to travel to Corinth.
Paul arrives and joins Aquila and Priscilla in tentmaking while establishing a new congregation.
Paul stays in the city for eighteen months teaching the word of God among the people.
Paul is brought before the judgment seat of Gallio and departs from the city.
Paul arrives at the port and has his hair clipped short because of a vow.
Paul sails from Cenchreae for Syria accompanied by Priscilla and Aquila.
Paul arrives and reasons with the Jews in the synagogue but soon departs for Caesarea.
Paul arrives at the seaport and then goes up to Jerusalem.
Paul arrives and greets the congregation before going down to Antioch.
Paul arrives back at his home base and spends some time there.
Paul departs on his third missionary tour through Galatia and Phrygia.
Paul arrives and finds several disciples who are rebaptized after his clarification.
Paul preaches in the synagogue for three months and then daily in the school of Tyrannus.
Paul continues his ministry in the school of Tyrannus and preaching from house to house.
Paul departs for Macedonia after a riot instigated by the silversmith Demetrius.
Paul stops at Troas but departs for Macedonia after not meeting Titus.
Paul arrives and is joined by Titus before writing his second letter to the Corinthians.
Paul arrives in Greece and stays for three months during the winter.
Paul departs and returns through Macedonia due to a plot by the Jews.
Paul arrives and stays for seven days resurrecting the young man Eutychus.
Paul arrives by foot and joins his companions on a ship.
Paul arrives and summons the older men of the Ephesian congregation for a meeting.
Paul arrives and is repeatedly warned through the spirit not to set foot in Jerusalem.
Paul arrives and spends the day visiting the brothers before traveling on.
Paul arrives and stays with Philip where Agabus prophesies his impending arrest.
Paul arrives and is arrested in the temple after being mobbed by Jews from Asia.
Paul stands trial before the Sanhedrin where he introduces the subject of the resurrection.
Paul departs for Caesarea under heavy guard after a plot against his life is discovered.
Paul arrives and is delivered to Governor Felix for trial.
Paul remains in custody as Felix hopes for a bribe to release him.
Paul stands trial before Festus and appeals to Caesar before departing for Rome.
Paul departs by ship as a prisoner in the custody of Julius.
Paul arrives at Sidon and is permitted to visit his friends.
Paul arrives and transfers to a grain ship from Alexandria bound for Italy.
Paul arrives with difficulty after quite a number of days due to adverse winds.
Paul arrives and recommends wintering there but his counsel is ignored.
Paul is shipwrecked on the island and survive a viper bite while healing many.
Paul departs on a ship from Alexandria after staying three months.
Paul arrives at the southern tip of Italy for a stop.
Paul arrives and spends one week with the Christian brothers.
Paul arrives and is permitted to stay in his own hired house under soldier guard.
Paul remains in captivity for two years preaching the Kingdom of God.
Paul completes his first imprisonment and is released by Caesar Nero.
Paul arrives and resumes his missionary activity before leaving Titus on the island.
Paul arrives and revisits congregations possibly writing his first letter to Timothy.
Paul arrives and encourages Timothy to stay in the city while Paul goes to Macedonia.
Paul arrives to spend the winter and is possibly arrested there.
Paul arrives for his second imprisonment and writes his second letter to Timothy.
Paul likely suffers martyrdom at the hands of Nero shortly after his final imprisonment.
Luke joins Paul and his party at this seaport following Paul's vision of a man from Macedonia.
Luke departs by sea for Neapolis in Macedonia with Paul and his companions.
Luke arrives in the city and begins sharing in the ministry to the women at the place of prayer.
Luke stays in the city to help establish and support the newly formed congregation after Paul departs.

Luke departs from the city by ship on the first leg of the voyage toward Jerusalem.

Luke arrives at the port and takes Paul on board for the continued voyage.
Luke departs with his companions and Paul to sail toward Miletus.

Luke departs on a ship bound for Italy as a companion to the prisoner Paul.
Luke arrives and observes Paul being permitted to receive kind treatment from his friends.
Luke departs with the company and sails along the coast toward Myra.
Luke arrives at the port and transfers to an Alexandrian ship carrying grain.

Luke arrives and waits while the harbor is deemed unsuitable for wintering.

Luke survives a violent shipwreck on the island and remains there for three months.
Luke departs on a ship from Alexandria that had wintered on the island.
Luke arrives and stays for three days before sailing on.
Luke departs for Rhegium at the tip of Italy.
Luke arrives at the port.
Luke departs and sails toward the Bay of Pozzuoli.
Luke arrives and spends one week staying with the local congregation.
Luke departs and travels on foot toward the city of Rome.

Luke departs with the group and the new companions to continue the trek.
Luke arrives and stays briefly at this station on the Appian Way.
Luke departs for the final leg of the journey into the city.
Luke arrives in the city where Paul is permitted to stay in his own hired house.
Luke stays with Paul during his imprisonment and likely begins writing the book of Acts.
Luke likely completes the book of Acts toward the close of Paul's two-year stay in Rome.
Luke remains the only constant companion of Paul during the apostle's final imprisonment.
Mark follows Jesus nearby wearing a fine linen garment but flees naked when the crowd tries to seize him.
Mark meets with the early Christian congregation at the home of his mother Mary.
Mark departs for Syrian Antioch with Barnabas and Saul after they complete their relief ministration.
Mark arrives in Syrian Antioch with his cousin Barnabas and Paul to assist in the ministry.
Mark departs from Antioch with Paul and Barnabas on their first missionary tour.
Mark arrives at the port of Seleucia to prepare for the voyage to Cyprus.
Mark sails away to Cyprus with Barnabas and Saul to proclaim the word of God.
Mark arrives on Cyprus and assists his companions as they preach in the synagogues.
Mark departs for Paphos while traveling through the whole island with Barnabas and Saul.
Mark arrives at the provincial capital and is present when the proconsul Sergius Paulus becomes a believer.
Mark puts out to sea from Paphos with his companions for the coast of Asia Minor.
Mark arrives in Pamphylia where he decides to leave his companions and return home.
Mark departs from the missionary group in Asia Minor to return to his family in Jerusalem.
Mark arrives back in Jerusalem after his withdrawal from the first missionary tour.
Mark departs for Cyprus with Barnabas after a sharp burst of anger separates Barnabas from Paul.
Mark arrives on the island of Cyprus with Barnabas to continue their missionary service.
Mark is with the imprisoned apostle Paul and serves as a strengthening aid and source of comfort.
Mark is in the process of composing his Gospel account which presents Jesus as a man of action.
Mark remains with Paul during his first imprisonment and is highly regarded for his service.
Mark is in the process of composing his Gospel account which presents Jesus as a man of action.
Mark is in close association with the apostle Peter in Babylon and sends greetings to fellow Christians.
Mark likely continues working on the Gospel account bearing his name.
Mark remains in Babylon where he serves as a valuable help to the apostle Peter.
Mark likely continues working on the Gospel account bearing his name.
Mark is associated with the apostle Peter in Babylon who addresses him affectionately as his son.
Mark likely continues working on the Gospel account bearing his name.
Mark departs for Rome to rejoin the apostle Paul at his request.
Mark arrives in Rome to assist Paul during his second imprisonment and is considered useful for ministering.
Mark completes his Gospel account while in Rome sometime during this year.
Joseph, surnamed Barnabas, sells a piece of land he owned and deposits the money at the feet of the apostles.
Barnabas comes to the aid of Saul and leads him to the apostles to confirm the details of his conversion.
Barnabas is sent out by the congregation in Jerusalem to travel as far as Antioch.
Barnabas arrives in Syrian Antioch and begins to encourage the new believers to continue in the Lord with heartfelt resolve.
Barnabas departs from the city to travel to Tarsus to make a thorough search for Saul.
Barnabas arrives in his hometown to find Saul and persuades him to help out in the ministry.
Barnabas departs from Tarsus and brings Saul back to Antioch.
Barnabas arrives in the city with Saul and they teach a considerable crowd in the congregation for a whole year.
Barnabas departs for Jerusalem with Saul to carry out a relief ministration due to a major famine.
Barnabas arrives in the city and completes the relief work before returning to Antioch.
Barnabas departs from the city and takes along John Mark.
Barnabas arrives back at his home base accompanied by Saul and John Mark.
Barnabas is set aside by holy spirit and sent off on a missionary tour with Saul.
Barnabas arrives at the port town and sails away for the island of Cyprus.
Barnabas arrives on Cyprus and begins proclaiming the word of God in the synagogues of the Jews.
Barnabas arrives at the provincial capital where the proconsul Sergius Paulus is converted to Christianity.
Barnabas and his companions put out to sea from Paphos to travel toward Asia Minor.
Barnabas arrives in Pamphylia where John Mark leaves his companions to return to Jerusalem.
Barnabas departs from Perga to travel toward Antioch in Pisidia.
Barnabas arrives in the city and finding much interest he preaches in the synagogue on the Sabbath.
Barnabas is thrown out of the city due to Jewish instigation and departs for Iconium.
Barnabas arrives and speaks in the synagogue helping many Jews and Greeks to become believers.
Barnabas departs for Lystra after learning of a plot by the Jews to stone him and Paul.
Barnabas arrives and is mistaken for the god Zeus by the crowds after the healing of a lame man.
Barnabas survives the persecution and departs for Derbe the following day.
Barnabas arrives and helps make quite a few disciples through his preaching of the good news.
Barnabas departs from the city to return to Lystra, Iconium, and Antioch to strengthen the disciples.
Barnabas arrives at the port town and departs by ship for Antioch in Syria.
Barnabas arrives back at his home base and reports to the congregation how God had opened the door of faith to the nations.
Barnabas departs for Jerusalem with Paul to settle a dispute regarding the circumcision of non-Jewish believers.
Barnabas arrives and relates the many signs and wonders God had done through them among the nations.
Barnabas departs for Antioch to deliver the letter containing the decision from the governing body.
Barnabas arrives back and spends some time teaching and declaring the good news.
Barnabas is led astray and joins other Jews in putting on a pretense when Peter separates himself from non-Jewish believers.
Barnabas is determined to take John Mark on a tour but departs separately after a sharp burst of anger with Paul.
Barnabas takes Mark along and sails away from the city to travel to Cyprus.
Barnabas arrives on his home island with his cousin Mark to continue his evangelizing work.
Barnabas continues to do further evangelizing work on the island with John Mark.
Barnabas continues to do further evangelizing work on the island with John Mark.
Silas is chosen by the apostles and elders to accompany Paul and Barnabas to Antioch.
Silas arrives in Antioch to deliver the letter containing the governing body's decision on circumcision.
Silas encourages the brothers in Antioch with many talks and strengthens them.
Silas is selected by Paul and departs on a missionary tour through Syria and Cilicia.
Silas departs through Syria with Paul to strengthen the congregations.
Silas travels through Cilicia with Paul to strengthen the congregations.
Silas departs from the seaport of Troas to sail for Macedonia in Europe.
Silas arrives in Macedonia at the seaport of Neapolis.
Silas arrives in the Roman colony of Philippi to preach the good news.
Silas is seized and beaten with rods by order of the civil magistrates.
Silas is thrown into prison and has his feet made fast in stocks.

Silas arrives in the thriving metropolis of Thessalonica and reasons from the Scriptures in the synagogue.

Silas departs from Beroea to rejoin Paul in Corinth.

Silas remains in Corinth teaching the word of God among the people.

Silvanus continues his faithful service with the apostle Peter in Babylon.
Silvanus completes his work with Peter as a faithful brother.
Timothy is a Christian disciple in the city who is well-reported on by the brothers in Lystra and Iconium.
Timothy is circumcised by the apostle Paul to remove a potential obstacle to the ministry among the local Jews.
Timothy departs from his hometown with Paul and Silas to share in Christian activities during the second missionary tour.
Timothy arrives in the city with Paul and Silas as they deliver the decrees decided on by the apostles in Jerusalem.

Timothy arrives in Ephesus with Paul during the third missionary tour and begins an extended period of service.
Timothy continues his ministry in the city where Paul preaches daily in the school auditorium of Tyrannus.
Timothy continues his ministry in the city as the word of Jehovah grows mightily and magic practitioners burn their books.
Timothy is sent by Paul to Macedonia in advance to minister to the brothers in that region.

Stephen is selected by the congregation as one of seven certified men to oversee the daily food distribution for widows.
Stephen performs great portents and signs among the people while full of divine favor and power.
Men from the Synagogue of the Freedmen argue with Stephen but cannot hold their own against his wisdom and spirit.
Stephen is seized and brought before the Sanhedrin after being falsely accused of speaking blasphemous words against Moses and God.
Stephen looks intently into heaven and sees the glory of God and Jesus standing at God's right hand while standing before the council.
Stephen is cast outside the city and stoned to death while he appeals to the Lord Jesus to receive his spirit.
Devout men carry Stephen to his burial and make a great lamentation over him.
Agabus departs from the city along with other prophets to travel toward Syrian Antioch.

Agabus departs from the region of Judea to travel down toward the seaport city of Caesarea.

Cornelius is a centurion of the Italian band who is described as a devout man fearing God and making supplication continually.
Cornelius receives a vision of an angel who informs him that his prayers and gifts of mercy have ascended as a remembrance before God.
Cornelius dispatches two of his house servants and a devout soldier to Joppa to summon Simon who is called Peter.
Cornelius waits in the city for the arrival of Peter while having called together his relatives and close friends.
Cornelius meets Peter at the door and falls down at his feet to do obeisance but is told to stand up as Peter is also a man.
Cornelius explains that an angel appeared to him four days prior and instructed him to send for Simon in Joppa.
Cornelius and his household listen intently as Peter declares the good news concerning the ministry and resurrection of Jesus Christ.
Cornelius and those with him receive the holy spirit and begin speaking in tongues and glorifying God while Peter is yet speaking.
Cornelius and his household are baptized in the name of Jesus Christ as the first uncircumcised Gentile converts to Christianity.
Cornelius requests that the apostle Peter remain with them for some days following their baptism.
Aquila departs from the city with his wife Priscilla following a decree by Claudius Caesar ordering all Jews to leave Rome.
Aquila arrives in the city after being expelled from Rome and begins working as a tentmaker.
Aquila welcomes the apostle Paul into his home and works with him in the trade of tentmaking.
Aquila remains in the city working at his trade and assisting Paul during the eighteen-month establishment of the congregation.
Aquila departs by sea from the city to travel toward Syria in the company of Paul and Priscilla.
Aquila arrives at the port before sailing away for the province of Asia.
Aquila arrives in the city and is left there by Paul to continue the ministry.
Aquila and Priscilla explain the way of God more accurately to Apollos after hearing him speak boldly in the synagogue.
Aquila hosts a congregation in his home and sends hearty greetings to the Christian brothers in Corinth.
Aquila departs from the city to return to Rome.
Aquila arrives back in the city and is commended by Paul as a fellow worker who risked his neck for the apostle's soul.
Aquila continues his service in the city while hosting a congregation in his house.
Aquila departs from the city to return to Ephesus during the final period of Paul's ministry.
Aquila is back in the city and is sent final greetings by the apostle Paul in his second letter to Timothy.
Priscilla departs from the city with her husband Aquila because Emperor Claudius had ordered all the Jews to depart from Rome.
Priscilla arrives in Corinth and begins working at the trade of tentmaking with her husband and the apostle Paul.
Priscilla remains in Corinth and continues to work at the trade of tentmaking while assisting the local congregation.
Priscilla departs from Corinth to travel toward Syria by ship accompanied by her husband Aquila and the apostle Paul.
Priscilla arrives in Ephesus where she remains after the apostle Paul continues his journey toward Jerusalem.
Priscilla and her husband take Apollos into their company and explain the way of God more accurately to him.
Priscilla remains in the city and provides hospitality to the congregation by hosting meetings in her home.
Priscilla remains in the city and provides hospitality to the congregation by hosting meetings in her home.
Priscilla sends her hearty greetings to the congregation in Corinth from Ephesus along with the congregation meeting in her house.
Priscilla departs from the city of Ephesus to return to Rome.
Priscilla arrives in Rome and is greeted by the apostle Paul as a fellow worker who risked her own neck for his soul.
Priscilla remains in the city and continues to host congregation meetings in her home and perform fine Christian works.
Priscilla remains in the city and continues to host congregation meetings in her home and perform fine Christian works.
Priscilla remains in the city and continues to host congregation meetings in her home and perform fine Christian works.
Priscilla remains in the city and continues to host congregation meetings in her home and perform fine Christian works.

Priscilla remains in the city and continues to host congregation meetings in her home and perform fine Christian works.
Priscilla departs from the city of Rome to travel back toward Ephesus.
Priscilla arrives in Ephesus and is sent final greetings by the apostle Paul during his second imprisonment in Rome.
Apollos departs from his home city in Egypt to travel toward the province of Asia.
Apollos arrives in the city and begins witnessing in the local synagogue with notable eloquence and conviction.
Apollos is taken into the company of Aquila and Priscilla who explain the way of God more accurately to him.
Apollos departs from the city to travel toward the region of Achaia while supplied with a letter of introduction.
Apollos arrives in the province and begins helping those who had believed through God's undeserved kindness.
Apollos centers his activity in the city where he powerfully confutes the arguments of the unbelieving Jews.
Apollos continues his ministry in the city and is described as watering what the apostle Paul had planted.
Apollos departs from the city to rejoin the apostle Paul in Ephesus.
Apollos stays in the city with Paul but declines to return to Corinth at that time despite the apostle's requests.
Apollos is on the island where Titus is urged to speed him and Zenas on their journey so they lack nothing.
Mary stands near the torture stake of Jesus during his execution and is entrusted by him to the care of the apostle John.
Mary departs from the place of Jesus' execution to go into the household of the apostle John.
Mary arrives at the home of the apostle John who takes her in to care for her as his own mother.
Mary assembles with the eleven apostles and other faithful ones in an upper chamber to persist in prayer after the ascension of Jesus.
James receives a personal appearance from the resurrected Jesus which likely leads to his conversion.
James meets with Paul during the apostle's first visit to Jerusalem following his conversion to Christianity.
James is identified by Peter as a prominent brother to whom the news of Peter's miraculous release from prison should be reported.
James presides over the meeting of the apostles and older men in Jerusalem to resolve the issue of circumcision for Gentile believers.
James and the older men welcome Paul back to the city and listen to his report on the progress of the ministry among the nations.
James serves as an overseer in the congregation and completes the writing of his inspired letter to the twelve tribes.
James finishes his course as a prominent overseer in the Jerusalem congregation upon his death during this year.
Jude assembles with the eleven apostles, his mother Mary, and other faithful disciples in an upper chamber to persist in prayer.
Jude is among the disciples present in Jerusalem who receive the holy spirit and begin to speak in different languages on the day of Pentecost.
Jude writes an inspired letter to fellow Christians to warn them about ungodly men slipping into the congregation and to encourage them to fight for the faith.
Simon is among the fleshly brothers of Jesus who assemble in an upper chamber to persist in prayer with the apostles and other disciples.
Simon is present as one of about 120 disciples in the city when Matthias is selected to replace Judas Iscariot as an apostle.
Peter delivers a powerful discourse on the day of Pentecost after the holy spirit is poured out on the disciples.
Peter heals a man who was lame from birth at the temple gate called Beautiful while in the company of John.
Peter is arrested and speaks boldly before the Sanhedrin regarding the salvation found only through Jesus Christ.
Peter rebukes Ananias and Sapphira for their deceptive actions against the holy spirit leading to their death.
Peter is sent by the apostles to travel to Samaria following reports that the people there had accepted the word of God.
Peter arrives in a city of Samaria and prays for the new believers to receive the gift of the holy spirit.
Peter strongly rebukes Simon the sorcerer for attempting to buy the authority to impart holy spirit with money.
Peter departs for Jerusalem while declaring the good news to many villages of the Samaritans.
Peter arrives back in Jerusalem after his successful preaching mission in Samaria.
Peter hosts the newly converted Saul in his home for fifteen days and listens to his testimony of meeting the Lord.
Peter departs from the city to travel through all the regions visiting the holy ones.
Peter arrives in Lydda and heals Aeneas who had been paralyzed and bedridden for eight years.
Peter departs for Joppa after receiving an urgent request from disciples following the death of Tabitha.
Peter arrives and resurrects the beloved sister Tabitha (Dorcas) after praying over her body in an upper room.
Peter stays for quite a few days in the city at the home of Simon, a tanner.
Peter receives a symbolic vision on a housetop regarding clean and unclean animals and meets messengers from Cornelius.
Peter departs with the messengers and some brothers to travel toward the seaport of Caesarea.
Peter arrives at the house of Cornelius and becomes the first to preach the good news to uncircumcised Gentiles.
Peter stays in the city for some days after witnessing the holy spirit being poured out on Cornelius and his household.
Peter departs from the city to travel to Jerusalem to address concerns raised by Jewish believers.
Peter arrives and explains the divine direction he received to preach to Gentiles causing the brothers to glorify God.
Peter is arrested by Herod Agrippa I and held in prison under heavy guard with the intent of execution.
Peter is miraculously released from prison by an angel of Jehovah during the night while the congregation prays.
Peter visits the home of Mary, mother of John Mark, to report his release before departing for another place.
Peter participates in the circumcision council testifying about God's acceptance of Gentiles through faith without the Law.
Peter arrives in Syrian Antioch but is later rebuked by Paul for withdrawing from eating with Gentile believers.
Peter resides in the city and writes his first inspired letter to the chosen ones scattered through various regions.
Peter remains in the city while continuing his ministry and oversight of the Christian congregations.
Peter concludes his work in the city as he prepares his second inspired letter to fellow believers.
John reclines next to Jesus at the Passover meal as the disciple whom Jesus loved.
John stands by the torture stake and is assigned by Jesus to care for his mother Mary.
John departs from the place of execution to take Mary into his own home.
John arrives at his home in the city with Mary to care for her.
John runs to the memorial tomb after hearing the report from Mary Magdalene.
John enters the tomb and sees the linen bandages and believes in the resurrection.
John departs from the city to travel to Galilee following the resurrection of Jesus.
John arrives at the Sea of Galilee and is present when the resurrected Jesus appears to seven disciples.
John recognizes the Lord on the shore and informs Peter that it is Jesus.
John departs for Jerusalem with the other apostles as they prepare for the ascension of Jesus.
John arrives in an upper room to meet with the other apostles and Mary to persist in prayer.
John and Peter heal a man lame from birth at the temple gate called Beautiful.
John is arrested with Peter and stands trial before the Sanhedrin to testify about Jesus.
John departs from the city after being sent by the apostles to assist new believers in Samaria.
John arrives and prays for the Samaritan disciples that they might receive holy spirit.
John departs for Jerusalem after giving a thorough witness and preaching in many villages.
John arrives back in the city to continue his oversight of the Christian congregation.
John remains in the city as an apostle helping to build up the early Christian congregation.
John is in the city when Saul makes his first visit to the apostles since his conversion.
John continues his ministry in the city as an apostle of the Christian congregation.

Matthew meets with the resurrected Jesus on a mountain and receives the commission to make disciples of all nations.
Matthew departs from Galilee to return to Jerusalem following his meeting with the resurrected Lord.
Matthew arrives in the city and gathers in an upper room with the other ten apostles following the ascension of Jesus.
Matthew persists in prayer with the apostles and other faithful ones including Mary the mother of Jesus and Jesus' brothers.
Matthew is present among the group of about 120 disciples when Matthias is chosen by lot to replace Judas Iscariot.
Matthew is filled with holy spirit on the day of Pentecost and begins speaking in different languages about the magnificent things of God.
Matthew and the other apostles join in summoning the disciples to appoint seven men for the distribution of food to needy widows.
Matthew remains in Jerusalem with the other apostles while most of the congregation is scattered due to intense persecution.
Matthew and the other apostles in Jerusalem hear that Samaria has accepted the word of God and send Peter and John to them.
Matthew is present when the apostles and older men meet in Jerusalem to consider the issue of circumcision for Gentile converts.

James is present with the other apostles when the resurrected Jesus appears to them behind locked doors.
James departs from the city to travel toward the region of Galilee as directed by the resurrected Christ.
James arrives at the sea and is one of the seven disciples to whom Jesus appears while they are fishing.
James departs from the region to return to Jerusalem for the period leading up to the festival of Pentecost.
James witnesses the ascension of Jesus Christ into heaven from the mountain near Bethany.
James arrives in the city and gathers with the apostles in an upper room to wait for the promised holy spirit.
James is present as one of the twelve apostles during the outpouring of holy spirit at Pentecost.
James remains in Jerusalem as a leading member of the congregation while other disciples flee because of intense persecution.
James continues his ministry as an apostle in the city of Jerusalem.
James remains in Jerusalem and serves as one of the apostles when Saul makes his first visit after his conversion.

James is put to death with the sword by Herod Agrippa I, becoming the first of the twelve apostles to die as a martyr.
Andrew departs from the mountain called Olivet to return to Jerusalem after witnessing the ascension of Jesus into heaven.
Andrew arrives in the city and goes to the upper chamber where he and the other apostles are staying.
Andrew persists in prayer along with the other apostles, several women, and the fleshly family of Jesus.
Andrew is present among approximately 120 disciples when Matthias is selected to replace Judas Iscariot as an apostle.
Andrew is filled with holy spirit on the day of Pentecost and begins to speak in a different language as the spirit enables him.
Philip asks Jesus to show the Father to the apostles while they are gathered for the final Passover meal.
Philip is among the eleven apostles who assemble in an upper room following the ascension of Jesus to persist in prayer.
Philip is present with the other disciples in the city when the holy spirit is poured out on the day of Pentecost.
Philip remains in the city with the other apostles while a great persecution scatters the congregation throughout Judea and Samaria.
Philip participates in the council of apostles and older men to determine the requirement of circumcision for non-Jewish believers.
Nathanael is seen by Jesus while under a fig tree before being called by Philip.
Nathanael is introduced to Jesus by Philip and recognized as an Israelite in whom there is no deceit.
Nathanael witnesses Jesus turning water into wine at a marriage feast in his hometown.
Bartholomew is chosen and appointed by Jesus as one of the 12 apostles.
Nathanael is present when the resurrected Jesus appears to seven disciples while they are fishing.
Nathanael stays in the fishing boat until it reaches the shore and joins the other disciples for breakfast with Jesus.
Bartholomew departs from the mountain called Olivet to return to Jerusalem after witnessing the ascension of Jesus.
Bartholomew arrives at an upper chamber and persists in prayer with the other apostles and disciples.
Bartholomew is present as an apostle when Matthias is selected by lot to replace Judas Iscariot.
Bartholomew is filled with holy spirit on the day of Pentecost and begins to speak in different languages.
Thomas is absent when Jesus first appears to the apostles but sees him eight days later and expresses his belief after being invited to touch Jesus' wounds.
Thomas is among the eleven apostles who gather in an upper room following the ascension of Jesus to persist in prayer.
Thomas is present in the city with the other disciples when the holy spirit is poured out on the day of Pentecost.
Thomas remains in the city with the other apostles while a great persecution scatters the congregation throughout Judea and Samaria.
Thomas participates in the council of apostles and older men to determine the requirement of circumcision for non-Jewish believers.
Simon the zealous one departs from the Mount of Olives to return to Jerusalem after witnessing the ascension of Jesus into heaven.
Simon the zealous one arrives in the city and goes to the upper chamber where he and the other apostles are staying.
Simon persists in prayer along with the other apostles, several women, and the fleshly family of Jesus in an upper room.
Simon is present as one of the apostles when Matthias is selected by lot to replace Judas Iscariot.
Simon is filled with holy spirit on the day of Pentecost and begins to speak in a different language about the magnificent things of God.
Simon remains in the city with the other apostles while a great persecution scatters the congregation throughout Judea and Samaria.
Simon participates in the council of apostles and older men to determine the requirement of circumcision for non-Jewish believers.
James meets with the resurrected Jesus on a mountain along with the other apostles and receives the commission to make disciples of all nations.
James departs from the region of Galilee to return to Jerusalem with the other apostles following the resurrection of Jesus.
James arrives in the city and gathers in an upper room with the other ten apostles to persist in prayer.
James is present among the group of about 120 disciples when Matthias is chosen by lot to replace Judas Iscariot as an apostle.
James is filled with holy spirit on the day of Pentecost and begins speaking in different languages about the magnificent things of God.
James and the other apostles summon the body of disciples to select seven reputable men to oversee the daily food distribution.
James remains in the city with the other apostles while a great persecution scatters the congregation throughout the regions of Judea and Samaria.
James participates in the meeting of the apostles and older men in Jerusalem to consider the issue of circumcision for Gentile converts.
Matthias is proposed as a candidate and then selected by lot to replace Judas Iscariot as one of the twelve apostles.
Matthias is filled with holy spirit on the day of Pentecost and begins to speak in a different language as the spirit enables him.
Matthias as one of the twelve apostles assists in summoning the disciples to appoint seven men to oversee the daily food distribution for widows.
Matthias remains in the city with the other apostles while the congregation is scattered throughout Judea and Samaria due to intense persecution.
Matthias and the other apostles in Jerusalem hear that Samaria has accepted the word of God and send Peter and John to them.
Matthias is present when the apostles and older men meet in Jerusalem to consider the issue of circumcision for Gentile converts.
Judas (not Iscariot) asks Jesus why he will show himself to the apostles and not to the world while they are gathered for the final Passover meal.
Thomas is absent when Jesus first appears to the apostles but sees him eight days later and expresses belief after being invited to touch Jesus' wounds.
Thomas departs from the city following the resurrection of Jesus to travel toward the region of Galilee.
Thomas is one of seven disciples present at the Sea of Galilee when the resurrected Jesus appears to them while they are fishing.
Thomas departs from the region of Galilee to return to the vicinity of Jerusalem for the period leading up to the ascension.
Judas (son of James) departs from the city following the resurrection of Jesus to travel toward the region of Galilee as directed by the Christ.
Judas (son of James) arrives in the region and meets with the resurrected Jesus on a mountain.
Judas (son of James) departs from the region to return to the vicinity of Jerusalem for the period leading up to the ascension.
Thomas arrives at the mountain called Olivet near Bethany and witnesses the ascension of Jesus into heaven.
Judas (son of James) arrives at the mountain called Olivet and witnesses the ascension of Jesus into heaven.
Thomas departs from the mountain called Olivet to return to Jerusalem after witnessing the ascension of Jesus into heaven.
Judas (son of James) departs from the mountain called Olivet to return to Jerusalem after witnessing the ascension of Jesus into heaven.
Thomas arrives in the city and gathers in an upper room with the other apostles following the ascension of Jesus.
Judas (son of James) arrives in the city and goes to the upper chamber where he and the other apostles are staying.
Judas (son of James) is present in the city when Matthias is selected by lot to replace Judas Iscariot as an apostle.
Thomas is present in the city with the other disciples when the holy spirit is poured out on the day of Pentecost.
Judas (son of James) is filled with holy spirit on the day of Pentecost and begins to speak in a different language.
Thomas remains in the city with the other apostles while a great persecution scatters the congregation throughout Judea and Samaria.

Lydia departs from her home city in the province of Lydia to travel toward Philippi where she conducts her business as a seller of purple.
Lydia arrives at a place of prayer by a river outside the city gate and listens to the apostle Paul declare the good news.
Lydia becomes a believer after Jehovah opens her heart to pay attention to the things Paul is saying.
Lydia is baptized along with her household and insists that Paul and his companions stay at her house if they judge her to be faithful to Jehovah.
Lydia welcomes Paul and Silas into her home after they are released from prison and provides them with encouragement.
Jason receives the apostle Paul and Silas with hospitality into his home during their visit to the city.
Jason is assaulted in his house by a mob of jealous Jews and dragged before the city rulers to face charges of sedition against Caesar.
Jason and other brothers are compelled by the city rulers to provide sufficient security in the form of a bond before being released.
Jason departs from the city to travel toward Corinth while in the company of the apostle Paul.
Jason arrives in the city and joins the apostle Paul in sending greetings to the Christian congregation in Rome.
Gaius is forcibly dragged into the theater by a riotous mob during an uproar instigated by the silversmith Demetrius.
Gaius departs from the city to travel toward Macedonia as a companion of the apostle Paul following the subsiding of the riot.
Gaius arrives in the region and travels through various parts giving encouragement to the disciples while in the company of Paul.
Gaius departs from the region to travel south into Greece as part of the missionary party.
Gaius arrives in the country where he begins a three-month stay while accompanying the apostle Paul.
Gaius continues his stay in the country for the remainder of a three-month period.
Gaius departs from the country and separates from Paul's party to travel ahead toward the seaport of Troas.
Gaius arrives in the seaport and waits for the arrival of the apostle Paul and his other traveling companions.
Gaius likely becomes a disciple as the apostle Paul and Barnabas arrive and declare the good news in the city during their first missionary tour.
Gaius remains in the city as a disciple following the departure of the apostle Paul and Barnabas for Antioch.
Gaius is forcibly taken into the theater during a riot instigated by the silversmith Demetrius while serving as a companion to the apostle Paul.
Gaius departs from the city of Ephesus with the apostle Paul to travel toward the province of Macedonia.
Gaius arrives in the province and continues to accompany the apostle Paul during the return leg of his third missionary journey.
Gaius departs from the province to travel toward Troas where he is assigned to wait for the arrival of the apostle Paul.
Gaius arrives in the city and waits for the apostle Paul to join the group after traveling ahead of him with other companions.
Gaius becomes a Christian disciple after the apostle Paul and Barnabas declare the good news and make many disciples in the city.
Gaius remains in the city as a Christian disciple following the departure of the apostle Paul and Barnabas for Antioch.
Gaius is personally baptized by the apostle Paul during the establishment of the Christian congregation in the city.
Gaius is seized by a rioting mob and forcibly taken into the theater during a confusion instigated by the silversmith Demetrius.
Gaius departs from the region of Macedonia to travel ahead of the apostle Paul toward the city of Troas.
Gaius arrives in the city and waits for the apostle Paul along with several other traveling companions.
Gaius provides hospitality as host to the apostle Paul and the entire congregation meeting in his home.
Gaius is personally baptized by the apostle Paul during the apostle's initial visit to the city to establish a Christian congregation.
Gaius serves as the host for the apostle Paul and the whole congregation while the apostle is in the city writing his letter to the Romans.
Aristarchus is forcibly taken into the theater by an angry mob during a riot instigated by the silversmith Demetrius.
Aristarchus departs from the city to travel toward the province of Macedonia in the company of the apostle Paul following the riot.
Aristarchus arrives in the province and continues to accompany the apostle Paul during his return through the region.
Aristarchus departs from the province to travel toward the city of Troas to wait for the arrival of the apostle Paul.
Aristarchus arrives in the city and waits for the apostle Paul to join the group after traveling ahead of him.
Aristarchus departs from the city to travel toward Jerusalem as part of the group delivering relief funds for the brothers.
Aristarchus arrives in the city with the apostle Paul and other companions to present the relief contribution to the congregation.
Aristarchus departs from the seaport on a voyage toward Rome to assist the apostle Paul during his journey.
